questions.text: Which of the following is the JVP finding in constrictive pericarditis?

choices.text: Prominent x descent and absent y descent with normal pressure
Absent x and y descents with elevated pressures
Absent x descent and prominent y descent with elevated pressure

questions.solution:
x and y descents are prominent in constructive pericarditis (blue arrows). Constrictive pericarditis is a disorder in which the pericardium is abnormal and inelastic. This thickened and rigid pericardium limits the complete filling of the ventricles in diastole by restricting the normal diastolic ventricular expansion. The pressures in all the chambers of the heart are elevated due to this external compression. The JVP is elevated as it reflects the right atrial pressures. Normally,

X-descent: Occurs due to relaxation of the right atrium during atrial diastole, it follows the 'a' wave which coincides with atrial contraction.

Y-descent: Occurs due to right ventricular filling; As blood moves from the right atrium to the ventricle, right atrial pressure drops.

Friedrich's sign describes a steep x/y descent seen in Pericarditis (although, in reality at the bedside, the waves are hard to discern)

Constrictive pericarditis has a chronic pathophysiology and develops slowly allowing the heart to develop compensatory mechanisms allowing 70-80% of the normal ventricular diastolic filing to occur in 25-30% of the diastolic duration leading to the rapid y descent. Although, rapid x descents occur in both constrictive pericarditis and cardiac tamponade, y-descent is not prominent in cardiac tamponade because tamponade occurs rapidly and impedes ventricular filing almost completely. It is a fatal condition requiring immediate treatment.

questions.text: All the following are absolute contraindications for liver transplantation EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Intrahepatic sepsis is a relative contraindication, not an absolute contraindication. It can be confused with uncontrolled extra-hepatobiliary infection which is an absolute contraindication. Contraindications for liver transplantation are:

Absolute contraindications

  • Uncontrolled extrahepatobiliary infection
  • Active, untreated sepsis
  • Uncorrectable, life-limiting congenital anomalies
  • Active substance or alcohol abuse
  • Advanced cardiopulmonary disease
  • Extrahepatobiliary malignancy (not including nonmelanoma malignancy skin cancer)
  • Metastatic malignancy to the liver
  • Metastatic malignancy to the liver
  • AIDS
  • Life-threatening systemic diseases

Relative contraindications

  • Age >70
  • Prior extensive hepatobiliary surgery
  • Portal vein thrombosis
  • Renal failure not attributable to liver disease
  • Previous extrahepatic malignancy (not including nonmelanoma skin cancer)
  • Severe obesity
  • Severe malnutrition/wasting
  • Medical noncompliance
  • HIV seropositivity with failure to control HIV viremia or CD4 <100/μL
  • Intrahepatic sepsis
  • Severe hypoxemia secondary to right-to-left intrapulmonary shunts (PO2 <50 mmHg)
  • Severe pulmonary hypertension (mean pulmonary artery pressure >35 mmHg)
  • Uncontrolled psychiatric disorder

questions.text: A patient with hyponatremia caused due to SIADH has which of the following features?

choices.text: Euvolemia, UNa< 40 mmol/L and Uosm< 100 mOsm/kg
Hypovolemia, UNa> 40 mmol/L and Uosm< 100 mOsm/kg
Euvolemia, UNa >40 mmol/L and Uosm >100 mOsm/kg
Hypovolemia, UNa <40 mmol/L and Uosm >100 mOsm/kg

questions.solution:
A patient with hyponatremia caused due to SIADH has euvolemia with UNa >40 mmol/L and Uosm >100 mOsm/kg. 

SIADH (Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion) is the most common cause of euvolemic hyponatremia. Excessive ADH acts on renal V2 receptors to increase free water retention, therefore only H2O is reabsorbed and not solutes making the urine concentrated (UNa >40 and Uosm >100) and the serum dilute producing hyponatremia.

SIADH is a condition where there is an inappropriate release of antidiuretic hormone or arginine vasopressin (AVP) from ectopic production of AVP. This may be from lung cancer and other neoplasms, increased release induced by various diseases, drugs, or exogenous administration of AVP. It is characterized by impaired water excretion leading to hyponatremia with euvolemia or hypervolemia. 

ADH promotes the reabsorption of water and not the solutes resulting in concentrated urine. This is depicted as high urine osmolality.

Patients usually present with hyponatremia with a euvolemic status. If hyponatremia develops acutely, signs and symptoms may include mild headache, confusion, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, coma, and convulsions. Chronic hyponatremia allows cerebral adaptation, and the patients are asymptomatic despite the hyponatremia.

Laboratory findings in SIADH include:

  • Hyponatremia: serum Na+<135 mEq/L
  • Urinary loss of Na+ >25 mEq per day or >40 mEq/L 
  • Urinary osmolality is >100 mOsm/kg
  • Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels are low, usually <10 mg/dL
  • Serum K+ and serum bicarbonate are normal

Treatment: Hyponatremia should be corrected gradually. Restriction of the total fluid intake. Sodium levels can be corrected using hypertonic saline. Tolvaptan and conivaptan are vasopressin receptor-2 antagonists that block the action of anti-diuretic hormones. Other drugs which are useful in the management are demeclocycline and fludrocortisone.

questions.text: In the hexaxial represenation of ECG leads, normal P wave is along which of the following directions
questions.solution:
The combined vector of the normal p wave is in the direction of Lead II which is 60°. The normal P wave is caused by depolarization of the atria arising from the sinus node. The direction of depolarization is towards the left and downward.

The P wave is therefore positive in Lead I, Lead II, Lead aVF and V4 to V6. 

The P wave is negative in lead aVR and biphasic in lead V1.

questions.text:
Which of the following newer biomarkers can be used for determining the prognosis of heart failure patients?
1.	Galectin-3
2.	NGAL
3.	Soluble ST-2
4.	IL-18
questions.solution: Soluble ST –2 and Galectin – 3 are newer biomarkers that can be used for determining the prognosis of HF patients. NGAL (Neutrophil gelatinase associated lipocalin) and IL-18 are novel biomarkers of acute kidney injury.

questions.text: Anticoagulation is recommended for which of the following patients with atrial fibrillation
questions.solution:
Option B is the most appropriate answer in this scenario.

To answer this question correctly, we need to know about CHA2DS2-VASc score. The 2012 ESC guidelines and 2014 ACC/AHA/HRS guidelines recommended the use of CHA2DS2-VASc score to access the risk of stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation.

CHA2DS2-VASc score

Treatment varies with the score

CHA2DS2-VASc score Treatment
≥ 2 Oral anticoagulants are recommended
1 Either oral anticoagulants, aspirin, or no antithrombotic therapy can be considered
0 Antithrombotic therapy may be omitted

In the above question, only option B has a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 2, while options A, C and D have a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 1. Therefore, option B is the best answer and oral anticoagulant is recommended in this case.

                                                                                                                          Score
Congestive HF 1
Hypertension 1
Age ≥ 75 years 2
Diabetes mellitus 1
Stroke/TIA/TE 2
Vascular disease 1
Age 65-74 years 1
Female gender (sex category) 1

questions.text:
Necrotizing vasculitis is classically seen in
1.	PAN
2.	Chrug-Strauss syndrome
3.	Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
4.	Microscopic polyangiitis
5.	IgA vasculitis
questions.solution: Necrotizing vasculitis is a feature of ANCA(Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic Antibody) associated vasculitis. Chrug-Strauss syndrome(Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis), microscopic polyangiitis and granulomatosis with polyangiitis(Wegener's granulomatosis) are all called ANCA associated vasculitis. Poly arteritis nodosa which is associated with hepatitis B infection and p-ANCA shows necrotizing vasculitis on microscopic examination.

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors for avascular necrosis of the hip except:
questions.solution:
Avascular necrosis (AVN) can affect almost any bone, but the head of the femur is by far the most commonly involved site. AVN can lead to cortical collapse of bone, with resultant accelerated osteoarthritis (OA) of the adjoining joint. Thus, OA is the result (not a cause) of AVN (Answer B). Pain is almost always the presenting complaint, but many cases can be entirely asymptomatic and discovered incidentally. The other conditions listed all increase the risk of AVN. Additional risk factors include

  • Gaucher's disease
  • High-dose corticosteroid therapy
  • Radiation
  • Trauma
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection
  • Decompression (Caisson’s) disease
  • Transplantation
  • Legg-Calve-Perthe disease
  • Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) syndrome

questions.text: The following histopathology slide of the kidney is seen in all of the following except
questions.solution:
The glomeruli are affected focally and segmentally. Hence this is a slide of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis.

Causes of FSGS are:

A.     Primary focal segmental glomerulosclerosis

B.     Secondary focal segmental glomerulosclerosis

C.     Viruses: HIV/hepatitis B/parvovirus

D.    Hypertensive nephropathy

E.     Reflux nephropathy

F.     Cholesterol emboli

G.    Drugs: Heroin/analgesics/pamidronate

H.    Oligomeganephronia

I.      Renal dysgenesis

J.      Alport’s syndrome

K.     Sickle cell disease

L.      Lymphoma

M.   Radiation nephritis

N.    Familial podocytopathies

O.    NPHS1 mutation/nephrin

P.     NPHS2 mutation/podocin

Q.    TRPC6 mutation/cation channel

R.     ACTN4 mutation/actinin

S.     α-Galactosidase A deficiency/Fabry’s disease N-acetylneuraminic acid hydrolase deficiency/nephrosialidosis

Hepatitis C is associated with cryoglobulinemic glomerulonephritis, membranous glomerulonephritis, and type I membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis in order of decreasing frequency.

questions.text: Tocilizumab is used in all of the following except
questions.solution:
Tocilizumab is not used in ankylosing spondylosis with uveitis.

Tocilizumab is an IL-6 antagonist. It is used for

  • Cytokine release syndrome, severe or life-threatening: Treatment of chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cell-induced severe or life-threatening cytokine release syndrome in patients ≥2 years of age
  • Giant cell arteritis: Treatment of giant cell arteritis (GCA) in adult patients
  • Polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis: Treatment of active polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis (pJIA) in patients ≥2 years of age
  • Rheumatoid arthritis: Treatment of adults with moderately to severely active rheumatoid arthritis (RA) who have had an inadequate response to one or more disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs)
  • Systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis: Treatment of active systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (SJIA) in patients ≥2 years of age

questions.text: Which of the following reduces the risk for developing ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)?

choices.text: Elevation of the head of the bed to 15 degrees to prevent aspiration
Twenty-four hours of prophylactic systemic antibiotics, especially if the intubation was emergent
Daily changing of the ventilatory circuit

questions.solution:
Frequent suctioning of the subglottic secretion reduces the risk of developing VAP. 

  • The strategies that can help reduce the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia in an intubated patient usually focus around preventing aspiration, reducing colonization of the airway and digestive tract, and minimizing contamination of the ventilatory circuit.
  • To prevent aspiration, the head of the bead should be maintained in a semirecumbent position (elevated 30–45 degrees) rather than in a fully recumbent position.
  • Cuffed endotracheal tube with cuff pressure set at ≥20 cm H2O with subglottic secretion drainage is to be used.
  • Routine use of oral or intravenous antibiotics for prophylaxis is not recommended.
  • To minimize contamination of the ventilatory circuit, the tubing should only be changed when visibly soiled or malfunctioning.

questions.text: Riociguat has therapeutic benefit in which of the following conditions
questions.solution:
• Riociguat has therapeutic benefit in pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) (WHO group 1) to improve exercise capacity, improve WHO functional class and to delay clinical worsening in adults.
  • Riociguat has therapeutic benefit in pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) (WHO group 1) to improve exercise capacity, improve WHO functional class and to delay clinical worsening in adults.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (PAH)

Drug Class Examples

Epoprostenol

Iloprost

Treprostinil

Bosentan

questions.text: Mr. X aged 40 years has a blood pressure of 138/84 mmHg on repeated measurements. Blood pressure in this case will be classified as
questions.solution:
According to 2017 AHA/ACC guidelines :

  • Normal blood pressure – Systolic <120 mmHg and diastolic <80 mmHg
  • Elevated blood pressure – Systolic 120 to 129 mmHg and diastolic <80 mmHg
  • Hypertension:
    • Stage 1 – Systolic 130 to 139 mmHg or diastolic 80 to 89 mmHg
    • Stage 2 – Systolic at least 140 mmHg or diastolic at least 90 mmHg

If there is a disparity in category between the systolic and diastolic pressures, the higher value determines the stage.

In this question patient has a higher diastolic blood pressure and is therefore classified as Stage 1 hypertension

Isolated systolic hypertension is defined as a blood pressure ≥130/<80 mmHg, and isolated diastolic hypertension is defined as a blood pressure <130/≥80 mmHg. Patients with a blood pressure ≥130/≥80 mmHg are considered to have mixed systolic/diastolic hypertension.

questions.text: Risk of Scleroderma renal crisis is increased with all of the following except
questions.solution:
Anti-centromere antibodies do not increase the risk of scleroderma renal crisis.

Scleroderma renal crisis presents with accelerated hypertension accompanied by acute kidney injury and progressive failure. This acute life-threatening complication of SSc occurs in 10–15% of patients. Risk factors for scleroderma renal crisis include African-American race, male sex, and diffuse or progressive skin involvement. Up to 50% of patients with scleroderma renal crisis have anti-RNA polymerase III antibodies, whereas patients with anti-centromere antibodies appear to be protected from this complication.

questions.text: Ustekinumab is an antibody which acts against
questions.solution:
Ustekinumab is a human monoclonal antibody that binds to and interferes with the proinflammatory cytokines, interleukin (IL)-12 and IL-23. Biological effects of IL-12 and IL-23 include natural killer (NK) cell activation, CD4+ T-cell differentiation and activation. Ustekinumab also interferes with the expression of monocyte chemotactic protein-1 (MCP-1), tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α), interferon-inducible protein-10 (IP-10), and interleukin-8 (IL-8). Significant clinical improvement in psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis patients is seen in association with reduction of these proinflammatory signalers.

JAK inhibitors-Tofacitinib, Baricitinib

Anti-IL-6 Antibody- Tocilizumab

Anti-IL-17 Antibody- Secukinumab and Brodalumab

questions.text: The B blood group antigen is structurally

choices.text: N acetyl galactosamine attached to H substance
N acetyl glucosamine attached to H substance

questions.solution:
The B blood group antigen is structurally Galactose attached to H substance.

A and B antigens are present on RBCs. These antigens are carbohydrates attached to a precursor backbone, may be found on the cellular membrane either as glycosphingolipids or glycoproteins, and are secreted into plasma and body fluids as glycoproteins. H substance is the immediate precursor on which the A and B antigens are added. This H substance is formed by the addition of fucose to the glycolipid or glycoprotein backbone. The subsequent addition of N-acetylgalactosamine creates the A antigen, whereas the addition of galactose produces the B antigen.

questions.text:
In which of the following conditions is the pulse in the given image seen?
  1. Aortic regurgitation
  2. Persistent ductus arteriosus
  3. Arteriovenous fistula 
  4. Aortic stenosis
  5. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
questions.solution:
The above image shows a water-hammer pulse (Corrigan’s pulse) which is seen in

  • Aortic regurgitation
  • Persistent ductus arteriosus
  • Arteriovenous fistula
  • Rupture of sinus of Valsalva

It is characterized by a rapid upstroke and a rapid downstroke. The rapid downstroke is due to the rapid run-off of blood into

  • the cavity of the left ventricle in AR
  • the pulmonary artery in PDA 
  • the veins in the case of AV fistula

 The rapid upstroke is due to increased stroke volume secondary to the hyperdynamic state.

Other options:

  • Aortic stenosis presents with pulsus parvus et tardus. It is seen as a low amplitude pulse that rises slowly and has a late peak.
  • HOCM presents with a bisferiens pulse. It is seen with a rapid upstroke to the first peak and a slower rise to the second peak.

Related Pearl: Different signs in Aortic Regurgitation

Sign

Description

De Musset's sign

  Head nodding with each heartbeat

Collapsing/Water Hammer/Corrigan pulse

 It is a bounding pulse with rapid upstroke  and descent

Lighthouse sign

  Alternate flushing & blanching of the forehead

Landolfi’s sign

  Alternating constriction and dilation of the pupil

Becker’s sign

  Retinal artery pulsations

Quincke’s pulse

 Alternate flushing and paling of the skin at the root of the nail while pressure is applied to the tip of the nail
Rosenbach’s sign  Pulsation of liver
Gerhardt’s sign  Pulsation over the spleen, detected in the presence of splenomegaly

Traube’s sign

 A pistol shot sound over femoral arteries

Durozeiz’s sign

 To-and-fro murmur over the femoral artery when lightly compressed with a stethoscope

Hill’s sign

 The systolic blood pressure of the lower limb exceeds that of the upper limb at least by 20mm Hg

Muller’s sign

Systolic pulsation of the uvula

questions.text: A patient has the following the ECG in his medical records, now the patient has developed atrial fibrillation with a BP of 90/60 mmHg. Which of the following is the best treatment
questions.solution:
DC cardioversion is the best treatment modality for the given ECG.

The ECG shows a wide QRS complex with a very short PR segment - Delta wave(black arrows).

Therefore the patient has WPW syndrome. Atrial fibrillation in a WPW syndrome patient can be fatal, as it can quickly progress to VT and VF. Normally the AV node conducts a few of the atrial impulses to the ventricles during AF, but in WPW syndrome the presence of the accessory pathway (bundle of kent )allows for conduction of all atrial impulses to the ventricles resulting in an extremely fast ventricular rate.

The treatment of WPW with AF with hemodynamic instability is DC cardioversion. Vagal maneuvers, adenosine and other AV node blocking agents will worsen the condition as the normal conduction pathway is blocked but the accessory pathway is still active. Defibrillation is used in ventricular fibrillation not in atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: All of the following are AIDS defining illnesses except:
questions.solution:
Oral candidiasis, although seen in AIDS patients, is not an AIDS-defining illness. Candidiasis of the esophagus, trachea, bronchi, and lungs are AIDS-defining illnesses. 

AIDS-defining illnesses are specific opportunistic illnesses in patients with AIDS, which signify an advanced stage of illness (Stage 3).

A case of HIV can be classified into five stages as per current CDC guidelines (0, 1, 2, 3, and unknown).

Stage

 Criteria CD4+ count (>5 years)

0

 A negative HIV test within 6 months of first diagnosis NA
1 Based on CD4+ count >=500
2 Based on CD4+ count 200-499
3 AIDS-defining opportunistic illness <200
unknown Unavailable CD4+ counts unknown

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix

questions.text: A patient with anxiety disorder is brought into the emergency room. The patient has a BP of 130/80 mm Hg, HR of 130 beats/min and a respiratory rate of 30 cycles/min. His ABG is likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Low PaCO2 is most likely to be seen in the patient's ABG.

The patient is hyperventilating with a respiratory rate of 30 cycles/min. Alveolar hyperventilation decreases PaCO2 and increases the HCO3/PaCO2 ratio, thus increasing pH and producing respiratory alkalosis. Anxiety disorders are often associated with respiratory alkalosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about pathology of Sjogren’s syndrome?

choices.text: Low levels of C4 complement is an adverse predictor of lymphoma development
T cell predominate in severe lesions of exocrine glands
Macrophages negative for IL-18 for correlated with parotid enlargement

questions.solution:
Low levels of C4 complement is an adverse predictor of lymphoma development.

Sjögren's syndrome is characterized by both lymphocytic infiltration of the exocrine glands and B lymphocyte hyperreactivity. The major infiltrating cells in the affected exocrine glands are activated T and B lymphocytes. T cells predominate in mild lesions, whereas B cells are dominant in more severe lesions. Macrophages and dendritic cells also are found. The number of macrophages positive for interleukin (IL) 18 has been shown to correlate with parotid gland enlargement and low levels of the C4 component of complement, both of which are adverse predictors for lymphoma development.

questions.text: All of the following are true about TTP except

choices.text: More common in women than men
Is associated with low levels of ADAMTS13

questions.solution:
• The pathogenesis of TTP is related to a deficiency of, or antibodies to, the metalloprotease ADAMTS13, which cleaves VWF. VWF is normally secreted as ultra-large multimers, which are then cleaved by ADAMTS13. The persistence of ultra-large VWF molecules is thought to contribute to pathogenic platelet adhesion and aggregation.
  • Idiopathic TTP appears to be more common in women than in men.
  • TTP is more common in patients with HIV infection and in pregnant women.
  • Findings to support the TTP diagnosis include an increased lactate dehydrogenase and indirect bilirubin, decreased haptoglobin, and increased reticulocyte count, with a negative direct antiglobulin test.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about HIT(Heparin induced thrombocytopenia)

choices.text: Doesnt occur with the use of lower molecular weight heaprin
Upper GI bleeding occurs and is more common than lower GI bleeding
Arterial and venous thrombosis can occur

questions.solution:
Both arterial and venous thrombosis can occur in HIT.

  • Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) is a life-threatening complication of exposure to heparin (ie,unfractionated heparin, low molecular weight [LMW] heparin).
  • HIT results from an autoantibody directed against endogenous platelet factor 4 (PF4) in complex with heparin. This antibody activates platelets and can cause catastrophic arterial and venous thrombosis with a mortality rate as high as 20 percent.
  • The thrombocytopenia is not usually severe, with nadir counts rarely <20,000/μL.
  • Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) is not associated with bleeding and, in fact, markedly increases the risk of thrombosis.

questions.text: Lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma is associated with which of the following
questions.solution:
Lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma is associated with Hepatitis C virus. Other infectious agents associated with development of lymphoid malignancies are

Infectious Agent Lymphoid Malignancy
Epstein-Barr virus

Burkitt,s lymphoma

Post-organ

Primary CNS diffuse large B-cell lymphoma Hodgkin,s lymphoma

Extranodal NK/T-cell lymphoma/lymphoma

 
HTLV-1 Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma
HIV

Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma

Burkitt,s lymphoma
Hepatitis C virus Lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma
Helicobacter pylori Gastric MALT lymphoma
Human hepesvirus 8

Primary effusion lymphoma

Multicentric castleman,s disease

questions.text: AML with which of the following mutations has an adverse prognosis
questions.solution:
AML with t(6;9)(p23;q34); DEK-NUP214 mutation has adverse prognosis. All the other options have a favorable prognosis.

AML genetics and prognosis

Genetic Group Subsets
Favorable t(8;21)(q22;q22); RUNX1-RUNX1T1 inv(16)(p13.1q22) or t(16;16)(p13.1;q22); CBFB-MYH11 Mutated NPM1 without FLT3-ITD (normal karyotype) Mutated CEBPA (normal karyotype)
Intermediate-I Mutated NPM1 and FLT3-ITD (normal karyotype) Wild-type NPM1 and FLT3-ITD (normal karyotype) Wild-type NPM1 without FLT3-ITD (normal karyotype)
Intermediate-II t(9;11)(p22;q23); MLLT3-MLLCytogenetic abnormalities not classified as favorable or adverse
Adverse inv(3)(q21q26.2) or t(3;3)(q21;q26.2); RPN1-EVI1 t(6;9)(p23;q34); DEK-NUP214 t(v;11)(v;q23); MLL rearranged –5 or del(5q); –7; abn(17p); complex karyotype (≥3 abnormalities)

questions.text: All of the following are true about ADPKD except

choices.text: Caused by mutations in PKD1 and PKD2
Most common stones are composed of uric acid
Increased incidence of renal cell carcinoma
Cardiovascular complications are the major cause of mortality

questions.solution:
Renal cell carcinoma is a rare complication of ADPKD with no apparent increased frequency compared to the general population.

ADPKD is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait with complete penetrance but variable expressivity. ADPKD is caused by mutations in PKD1 and PKD2, which, respectively, code for polycystin-1 (PC1) and polycystin-2 (PC2). It is characterized by the progressive bilateral formation of renal cysts. Many patients are asymptomatic until the fourth to fifth decade of life. Kidney stones occur in ~20% of patients with ADPKD. Different from the general population, more than half of the stones in patients with ADPKD are composed of uric acid, with the remainder due to calcium oxalate. Cardiovascular complications are the major cause of mortality in these patients followed by infections. Intracranial aneurysm (ICA) occurs four to five times more frequently in ADPKD patients than in the general population and causes high mortality.

questions.text: Mesangial proliferation is defined as ________ class of lupus nephritis according to International Society of Nephrology-Renal Pathology Society Study group
questions.solution:
Lupus Nephritis is classified into 6 classes, which are

Class I Minimal mesangial Normal histology with mesangial deposits
Class II Mesangial proliferation Mesangial hypercellularity with expansion of the mesangial matrix
Class III Focal nephritis Focal endocapillary± extracapillary proliferation with focal subendothelial immune deposits and mild mesangial expansion
Class IV Diffuse nephritis Diffuse endocapillary ± extracapillary proliferation with diffuse subendothelial immune deposits and mesangeal alterations
Class V Membranous nephritis Thickened basement membranes with diffuse subepithelial immune deposits; may occur with class III or IV and is sometimes called mixed membranous and proliferative nephritis
Class VI Sclerotic nephritis Global sclerosis of nearly all glomular capillaries

questions.text: A patient develops prosthetic valve endocarditis 2 years after valve replacement surgery. Which of the following organism is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Patient developing endocarditis 2 years after prosthetic valve surgery suggests late-onset endocarditis. In such cases, the most common causative organism is streptococci.

Related Pearl: Microbiology of Infective Endocarditis

questions.text: All of the following are true about contrast nephropathy except

choices.text: Risk is higher with solitary kidney and diabetic nephropathy
S. creatinine begins to fall 48 hrs after exposure

questions.solution:
In contrast nephropathy, S. creatinine starts to rise at 24-48 hours peaks on day 5 and returns to baseline usually by 1-2 weeks.

Contrast nephropathy is defined as a rise in serum creatinine of at least 85 μmol/L (1 mg/dL) within 48 h of contrast administration. The prognosis is usually favorable. Risk factors for contrast nephropathy include advanced age (>80 years), preexisting renal disease (serum creatinine exceeding 2 mg/dL), solitary kidney, diabetes mellitus, dehydration, paraproteinemia, concurrent use of nephrotoxic medication or chemotherapeutic agents, and high contrast dose.

The risk of contrast nephropathy increases in patients with an eGFR <60 mL/min/1.73 m2; however, the majority of these patients will only have a temporary rise in creatinine.  If contrast must be administered to a patient with an eGFR below 45 mL/min/1.73 m2, the patient should be well hydrated, and a reduction in the dose of contrast should be considered.

Note : Several causes of ischemia-associated and nephrotoxin-associated AKI can present with FeNa <1%, including sepsis (often early in the course), rhabdomyolysis, and contrast nephropathy.

questions.text: Oliguria is defined as urine output less than
questions.solution:
Oliguria is defined as urine output less than 400ml/day

Anuria is defined as urine output less than 100ml/day

questions.text: Which of the following is true about calcium oxalate stones

choices.text: Diet low in calcium is advised
Diet low in sodium is advised
High dose vitamin C has some benefit

questions.solution:
• Calcium oxalate stones are the most common renal calculi.
  • Risk factors for calcium oxalate stones include higher urine calcium, higher urine oxalate, and lower urine citrate. This stone type is insensitive to pH in the physiologic range.
  • Dietary calcium restriction is not beneficial and, in fact, is likely to be harmful.
  • Reducing sodium intake to <2.5 g/d is advised as it may decrease urinary excretion of calcium.
  • High-dose vitamin C supplements should be avoided, as vit c is excreted in the oxalate form and hence increased risk for stone formation .
  • While bisphosphonates may reduce urine calcium excretion in some individuals, there are no data on whether this class of medication can reduce stone formation; therefore, bisphosphonates cannot be recommended solely for stone prevention at present.
  • A thiazide diuretic, in doses higher than those used to treat hypertension, can substantially lower urine calcium excretion and can prevent calcium oxalate stones.

questions.text: All of the following are true about hepatorenal syndrome except

choices.text: In Type 1 HRS there is significant reduction in creatinine clearance within 1–2 weeks of presentation
Type 2 HRS is associated with a better outcome than that of type 1 HRS

questions.solution:
• The hepatorenal syndrome (HRS) is a form of functional renal failure without renal pathology that occurs in about 10% of patients with advanced cirrhosis or acute liver failure. There are marked disturbances in the arterial renal circulation in patients with HRS; these include an increase in vascular resistance (renal vasoconstriction) accompanied by a reduction in systemic vascular resistance.
  • Based upon the rapidity of the decline in kidney function, two forms of hepatorenal syndrome have been described
  • Type 1 hepatorenal syndrome – Type 1 hepatorenal syndrome is the more serious type; it is defined as at least a twofold increase in serum creatinine (reflecting a 50 percent reduction in creatinine clearance) to a level greater than 2.5 mg/dL (221 micromol/L) during a period of less than two weeks.
  • Type 2 hepatorenal syndrome – Type 2 hepatorenal syndrome is defined as renal impairment that is less severe than that observed with type 1 disease. The major clinical feature in patients with type 2 hepatorenal syndrome is ascites that is resistant to diuretics.
  • Patients are treated with midodrine, an α-agonist, along with octreotide and intravenous albumin.
  • The best therapy for HRS is liver transplantation; recovery of renal function is typical in this setting.

questions.text: Which of the following Neuraminidase inhibitors used as treatment for influenza is administered by inhalation
questions.solution:
All the options are  Neuraminidase inhibitors used as treatment for influenza.

  • Zanamivir is administered by inhalation and is well tolerated, but may result in bronchospasm and should be avoided in susceptible patients, such as those with asthma or COPD
  • Oseltamivir is administered orally
  • Peramivir is given by injection and is FDA (United States Food and Drug Administration) approved as a single dose for uncomplicated influenza.

questions.text: All of the following are components of CURB-65 score used to access indications for hospitalization in patients with suspected community acquired pneumonia EXCEPT
questions.solution:
CURB-65 score used to access indications for hospitalization in patients with suspected community acquired pneumonia. Respiratory rate ≥ 30 cycles/min is given one point not ≥ 20.

PSI- Pneumonia severity Index is the other score which is used.

questions.text: All of the following are true about polycythemia vera rubra except

choices.text: Basophilia and eosinophilla are frequently present

questions.solution:
• Polycythemia vera is an acquired myeloproliferative disorder that causes overproduction of all three hematopoietic cell lines, most prominently the red blood cells.
  • According to the WHO 2017 criteria, the hallmark of polycythemia vera is a hematocrit (at sea level) that exceeds 49% in males or 48% in females.
  • Erythroid production is independent of erythropoietin, and the serum erythropoietin level is low. RBC morphology is normal.
  • JAK2 (V617F) mutation has been demonstrated in 95% of cases.
  • Usually elevated white blood count and platelet count. Basophilia and eosinophilia are frequently present.
  • Thrombosis is the most common complication of polycythemia vera and the major cause of morbidity and death in this disorder.
  • Vitamin B12 levels are strikingly elevated because of increased levels of transcobalamin III (secreted by white blood cells). Overproduction of uric acid may lead to hyperuricemia.
  • The treatment of choice is phlebotomy.

questions.text: Which of the following does not respond to normal bicarbonate therapy
questions.solution:
Type 2 renal tubular acidosis is a proximal renal tubular defect in HCO3 resorption leading to a mild acidosis. Administration of NaHCO3 results in alkaline urine despite systemic acidosis because adequate renal HCO3 resorption does not occur.

Characteristics of Renal tubular acidosis are:

  Type 1 Type 2 Type 4
Basic defect Distal defect in H+ defect Proximal tubular defect in HCO3− resorption Hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism
Serum pottasium Low Low to normal High
Able to acidify urine to pH <5.5 No Yes Yes
Responds to NaHCO3 Yes No  Yes

questions.text: What is the target hemoglobin concentration in CKD
questions.solution: Current practice is to target a hemoglobin concentration of 10.0–11.5 g/dL in CKD. A normocytic, normochromic anemia is observed in CKD. The primary cause of anemia is insufficient production of erythropoietin (EPO). There has been an indication that the use of ESA(erythropoietin stimulating agents) in CKD may be associated with an increased risk of stroke in those with type 2 diabetes, an increase in thromboembolic events, and perhaps a faster progression to the need for dialysis. Therefore, any benefit in terms of improvement of anemic symptoms needs to be balanced against the potential cardiovascular risk. Complete normalization of the hemoglobin concentration has not been demonstrated to be of incremental benefit to CKD patients.

questions.text: BASDAI scoring system is used in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution: Bath Ankylosing Spondylitis Disease Activity Index (BASDAI) is a disease activity score used to monitor response to treatment to ankylosing spondylosis. Ankylosing Spondylitis Disease Activity Score (ASDAS) is another scoring system that is also used.

questions.text: Argatroban is a
questions.solution:
Argatroban is a parentral direct thrombin inhibitor

Direct thrombin inhibitors inactivate circulating and clot-bound thrombin (factor IIa).

Parenteral direct thrombin inhibitors

  • Bivalirudin
  • Argatroban
  • Desirud

Oral direct thrombin inhibitor—Dabigatran is the only oral direct thrombin inhibitor available for clinical use.

Direct factor Xa inhibitors

  • Rivaroxaban
  • Apixaban
  • Edoxaban
  • Betrixaban

questions.text: An 18-year-old man presents with acute kidney injury 3 days after an upper respiratory tract infection, with a rise in creatinine from 0.9 to 1.6 mg/dL. The patient’s urinalysis reveals 2+ blood and 2+ protein. C3 and C4 are normal. Serologic workup is negative for ANCA and anti-GBM. SPEP and UPEP are within normal limits. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: IgA nephropathy can present as a rapidly progressing glomerulonephritis (biopsy with crescentic IgA nephropathy), as a latent finding of hematuria and proteinuria, or in the setting of an upper respiratory tract infection (“synpharyngitic hematuria”), as is the case in this patient. IgA nephropathy typically occurs 1–3 days after an upper respiratory tract infection, as opposed to postinfectious GN, which occurs 7–21 days after an infection. The presence of normal complements also helps to distinguish IgA nephropathy from postinfectious GN. Thin basement membrane disease can be associated with some hematuria but does not fit the clinical picture. Alport syndrome can be associated with proteinuria, hearing loss, and progression to ESRD, but it does not fit the clinical picture. Granulomatous polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener’s granulomatosis) is unlikely with a negative ANCA.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the auscultatory finding of a fourth heart sound (S 4) on physical examination?

choices.text: A hallmark of the onset of atrial fibrillation

questions.solution: An S4 indicates increased left ventricular stiffness and is commonly heard in adults with hypertension. It is caused by the increased filling in late diastole during atrial contraction. An S4 is never normal. S4 is absent in atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: Which statement is false regarding serum brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) levels?

choices.text: Serum BNP levels may be in the reference range in patients with advanced heart failure
A persistently elevated serum BNP level despite optimal medical therapy is a marker of poor prognosis in heart failure
Optimization of medical therapy based on serum BNP levels decreases hospitalizations in heart failure
The serum BNP level is frequently elevated in idiopathic constrictive pericarditis

questions.solution: Although serum BNP levels correlate with clinical severity, some patients with advanced heart failure have normal BNP levels. Several large clinical trials have shown that a persistently elevated BNP level despite ongoing medical therapy is a marker of poor prognosis. A BNP-guided approach to titrate medical therapy has been shown to decrease hospitalizations compared with standard therapy. Although the serum BNP level is frequently elevated in constrictive pericarditis due to cardiac surgery or radiotherapy, it is frequently within the normal range in patients with idiopathic constrictive pericarditis.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding clostridium difficile infection?

VRE- Vancomycin-resistant enterococcal

choices.text: Vancomycin is less effective than metronidazole for treating severe disease
Most relapses are due to antibiotic resistance
VRE colonization occurs more frequently with oral vancomycin than metronidazole
Single episode of reinfection increases likelihood of relapses

questions.solution:
The true statement about Clostridium difficile from the above-mentioned options is that a single episode of reinfection increases the likelihood of further relapses.

Clostridium difficile is an obligate anaerobe. It is the most common cause of infectious diarrhea in hospitalized patients. Clostridium toxins are produced by inhibition of protein synthesis. Those who have 1 episode are predisposed to recurrences and those with 2 or more episodes are at highest risk for multiple relapses. The infection is strongly associated with prior use of antibiotics. The most common manifestation of Clostridium difficile infection is diarrhea. Other less common features are abdominal pain and paralytic ileus. Complications include sepsis and toxic megacolon. Investigation modalities include stool culture, endocscopy and PCR. 

Other options:

Option A: Oral vancomycin is more effective than metronidazole for the treatment of severe disease.

Option B: Most relapses result from reinfection or germination of spores, not from antibiotic resistance.

Option C: VRE(Vancomycin-resistant enterococcal) colonization often occurs in similar populations of patients who have received broad-spectrum antibiotics; however, there is no difference in VRE colonization whether patients receive vancomycin or metronidazole for the treatment of C. difficile infection. Fllow-up stool toxin assays to test for cure should be avoided because stool toxin assays may remain positive during and after successful treatment.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic criteria for Clostridium difficile infection

 

The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:

1.Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause      

2.Detection of toxins A or B in the stool by PCR or culture

               or               

 Detection of pseudomembranes in the colon

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: What is the goal with allopurinol therapy in the treatment of hyperuricemia in gout patients?

choices.text: Decrease the uric acid level to 8.0 mg/dL or less
Prevent further gout attacks without regard to uric acid level
Decrease the uric acid level to less than 6.0 mg/dL
Decrease urinary uric acid excretion to normal

questions.solution: The goal of allopurinol therapy in the treatment of gout is to decrease the uric acid level to less than 6.0 mg/dL. The solubility quotient of uric acid is 6.8 mg/dL. Therefore, decreasing the uric acid level to less than 6.0 mg/dL promotes shrinkage of tophi and results in better clinical efficacy.

questions.text: All of the following are true about peripartum cardiomyopathy except

choices.text: Tocolytic therapy is a risk factor

questions.solution:
PPCM is defined as newly diagnosed systolic cardiomyopathy (LVEF < 45% or fractional shortening < 30%) without a reversible cause, presenting between the last month of gestation and 5 months postpartum(Harrison’s says 6 months) most commonly in the first month postpartum) in a woman without known CVD.

Risk factors include

  • Multiparity
  • Multiple gestation
  • Diabetes
  • Family history
  • Race/ethnicity (eg, African American)
  • Smoking
  • Cocaine use
  • Long-term (> 4 weeks) use of beta-adrenergic tocolytic therapy (eg, terbutaline)
  • Hypertension, and preeclampsia

Endomyocardial biopsy usually does not add useful information that warrants the risk of the procedure and shows tissue edema, myocardial hypertrophy, and varying degrees of fibrosis.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with a diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia with a blood type O negative blood group presents to the transplant clinic to discuss proceeding with an allogeneic stem cell transplant. Which of the following would be an optimal donor?

choices.text: His HLA identical 50-year-old brother who is otherwise healthy and is blood type O+
An HLA identical matched unrelated donor who is blood type O–

questions.solution:
In the case of acute myeloid leukemia (AML), allogeneic stem cell transplants are the treatment of choice. His HLA identical 50-year-old brother who is blood type O positive would be the best choice.

Other options:

Option A: An identical twin brother would not be the donor of choice. The therapeutic benefit of stem cell transplant in hematological malignancies is due to the graft-versus-leukemia (GvL). Donor T lymphocytes attack malignant hematopoietic stem cells of the recipient that remain after high-dose chemotherapy. Despite having a low rate of graft versus host disease (GvHD), stem cells from an identical twin do not have a desirable degree of GvL effect, leading to higher rates of recurrence post-transplant. 

Option B: Autologous (umbilical cord transplant) is not recommended as higher rates of relapse have been reported.

Option D: An HLA identical sibling is preferred over an unrelated HLA identical donor because there is a greater chance of matching for minor histocompatibility complex (mHC). This reduces the risk of GvHD. ABO compatibility is also important to consider, but a minor ABO mismatch (Rh mismatch) doesn't have any impact on hemolysis, graft-versus-host disease, or survival.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man is noted to have an extra heart sound shortly after S2. Which of the following is not a possible cause of that sound?
questions.solution:
S2 coincides with closure of the aortic and pulmonic valves.

Option A: Opening snap of mitral stenosis is a high frequency sound that occurs shortly after S2. It is generated when the superior bowing of the anterior mitral leaflet during systole rapidly reverses direction toward the left ventricle in early diastole, owing to the high left atrial (LA) pressure.

Option B: Third heart sound is a low-frequency sound that is thought to be caused by sudden limitation of LV expansion during brisk early diastolic filling.

Option C: Ejection click is an early systolic sound(occurs between S1 and S2) that represents opening of an abnormal semilunar valve, characteristically a bicuspid aortic valve.

Option D: In constrictive pericarditis, a pericardial “knock” may be heard during the rapid filling phase of early diastole as the high-pressure atria rapidly decompress into relatively noncompliant ventricles.

questions.text: Which of the following regarding the effect of the potassium concentration on the ECG is TRUE?

choices.text: The earliest electrocardiographic sign of hyperkalemia is a reduction in P wave amplitude
Prominent U waves are a characteristic feature of hyperkalemia
QRS complex widening is common in severe hyperkalemia

questions.solution:
Hyperkalemia is associated with a distinctive sequence of electrocardiographic abnormalities, beginning with narrowing and peaking (tenting) of the T wave, with a shortened QT interval. Progressive hyperkalemia reduces atrial and ventricular resting membrane potentials, which inactivates sodium channels and decreases conduction velocity. At that stage, the QRS complex begins to widen and the P wave amplitude decreases. Complete loss of observed P waves may occur. In that situation, sinus rhythm typically persists but the P wave amplitude is so small that it is not recorded on the surface ECG. Very marked hyperkalemia leads to asystole, sometimes preceded by a slow undulatory (sinusoidal wave) pattern on the ECG caused by marked QRS widening.

Hypokalemia, in contrast, is associated with hyperpolarization of the resting membrane potential and increased action potential duration. This results in resting ST-segment depression and QT interval prolongation. The T waves often become flat, whereas U waves become prominent. The QT prolongation predisposes to torsades de pointes. Hypokalemia, not hyperkalemia, predisposes to digitalis-associated tachyarrhythmias.

questions.text: The incidence of transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is greatest with transfusion of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is the most common cause of transfusion related fatalities. TRALI usually results from the transfusion of donor plasma that contains high-titer anti-HLA class II antibodies that bind recipient leukocytes.

The risk of TRALI is related to the potential number of exposures to plasma from different sources. The greatest risk occurs when multiple pooled sources are used, as in platelet transfusions. The transfusion of pooled products from women, in particular fresh frozen plasma, has also been associated with an increased risk of TRALI.

The recipient develops symptoms of hypoxia (Pao2/FIo2 <300 mmHg) and signs of noncardiogenic pulmonary edema, including bilateral interstitial infiltrates on chest x-ray, either during or within 6 h of transfusion. Treatment is supportive, and patients usually recover without sequelae.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about peripheral edema in heart failure is correct?

choices.text: Edema in heart failure correlates well with the level of systemic venous pressure
Peripheral edema may be detected when extracellular fluid volume has increased by as little as 1 to 2 liters
Rupture of the skin with extravasation of fluid is more likely to occur with chronic volume overload than with the sudden development of edema
In patients with hemiplegia due to a cerebrovascular accident, edema is usually more apparent on the paralyzed side

questions.solution:
Edema is usually more marked on the paralyzed side of patients with hemiplegia; unilateral edema may also result from venous obstruction.

Although peripheral edema is a common and important physical finding in congestive heart failure, its presence does not correlate well with the level of systemic venous pressure. The excess volume of extracellular fluid is a more important determinant of edema. In adults, a minimum of 4 liters of excess extracellular fluid volume usually must accumulate before peripheral edema develops. In patients with chronic left ventricular failure and low cardiac output, peripheral edema may develop in the presence of normal or minimally elevated systemic venous pressure because of a gradual but persistent accumulation of extracellular fluid volume.

In rare instances, especially when edema develops suddenly and severely, frank rupture of the skin with extravasation of fluid may result.
